content.raw:
In free space, I would expect to see a mix of cases A (30m) and B (30m-epsilon).  That's because we're adding zero-mean noise to the raw reading of 30m, then [clamping](https://bitbucket.org/osrf/gazebo/src/e7a3fa0ce69fbc112716fe2760d3907e47409a6f/gazebo/sensors/GpuRaySensor.cc?at=default#cl-575) the result to lie between the device's minimum and maximum ranges.

Case C is curious.  Certainly, as @iche033 suggests, if the laser sees some part of the robot's body, then the 0.1m reading could be explained.  I haven't seen short readings like that happen in free space.

In free space, I would expect to see a mix of cases A (30m) and B (30m-epsilon). That's because we're adding zero-mean noise to the raw reading of 30m, then clamping the result to lie between the device's minimum and maximum ranges.

Case C is curious. Certainly, as @iche033 suggests, if the laser sees some part of the robot's body, then the 0.1m reading could be explained. I haven't seen short readings like that happen in free space.
